text: I keep seeing if an adventure mode needs to exist then why not just start a char at 68. then a couple months after that we'll see post about how people want to start at 90 just so they can kill bosses. Then a few months later we'll see people asking for a"creative" mode so they can have access to all items in the game so they don't have to farm, and i dont think that sets a good example as a community for a game that we all love.
actual_label:
'answer: slippery slope'

the reasoning behind this is that the argument posits a chain of events (start at 68, then 90, then creative mode) where each step is seen as a logical progression from the previous one. however, this assumption does not hold up in reality because not all players will necessarily follow this path once they have access to certain features or abilities. furthermore, the argument attempts to use this hypothetical chain of events to justify a negative conclusion about the community and its behavior, which is an unwarranted generalization based on a sequence of speculative assumptions.

text: That leads to me believe that most cat lovers are really shy.
actual_label: answer: answer: false cause

text: Someone once told me they have an"alt" cause their main account was too high of rank to play with their friends. It's exactly the same as smurfing.
actual_label:
answer: equivocation
explanation: the term "alt" (alternate account) is being used in a non-standard way, which makes the argument misleading. in gaming context, an alt account is usually created for reasons other than playing with friends, such as boosting ranks or trying out new strategies. therefore, it's not exactly the same as smurfing (creating a lower-ranked account to play against less skilled players), even though there might be some similarities in motivation.

text: Joe Biden will lose to Trump if he is the nominee. The Democratic party clearly has not learned the right lesson from Hillary Clinton's miserable failure.
actual_label:
answer: false cause
explanation: the argument assumes that the loss of hillary clinton in 2016 was caused by a failure on the part of the democratic party to learn the "right" lesson, but this is unproven and not based on evidence or reason. instead, it relies on the premise that clinton's loss was due to a lack of learning, without any supporting evidence provided in the argument.

text: Joe Biden will lose to Trump if he is the nominee. The Democratic party clearly has not learned the right lesson from Hillary Clinton's miserable failure. NOBODY WANTS ESTABLISHMENT POLITICIANS ANYMORE. NOBODY LIKES THE STATUS QUO.
actual_label:
'answer: appeal to emotion'
explanation: the argument relies on emotional language such as "miserable failure" and "nobody wants..." to make its point, rather than providing evidence or reason for the claim that joe biden will lose if he is the nominee. this is a fallacy where emotions are manipulated to support an argument without any real basis in evidence or reasoning.

text: The Democratic party clearly has not learned the right lesson from Hillary Clinton's miserable failure. NOBODY WANTS ESTABLISHMENT POLITICIANS ANYMORE. NOBODY LIKES THE STATUS QUO.
actual_label:
answer: hasty generalization

explanation: the statement claims that "nobody" wants establishment politicians anymore and nobody likes the status quo based on hillary clinton's loss, which is a hasty generalization. it is not reasonable to assume that the preference of all people (i.e., "nobody") can be determined by a single political event or figure. additionally, the statement ignores other possible factors that may have influenced clinton's loss, such as her campaign strategy, personal scandals, and voter attitudes on various issues.

text: The status quo in America is that its the best its ever been. We live in one of the best societies in the best times that humans have ever experienced.
actual_label: answer: appeal to tradition

text: America is the best place to live, because it's better than any other country.
actual_label: answer: circular reasoning

text: Let us move now to the future. It is not enough to stand on this record because we are dealing with the most ruthless, fanatical... leaders that the world has ever seen.
actual_label: 'answer: appeal to fear'

text: That is why I say that in this period of the sixties, America must move forward in every area.
actual_label:
answer: nothing (or possibly "begging the question", depending on how you interpret the statement)
explanation: while it may appear that the speaker is using a logical argument to justify their position, they are not actually providing any evidence or reasoning for why this period of the sixties requires america to move forward in every area. instead, they are simply stating their opinion without providing justification, and thus no fallacy is being committed. if, however, we interpret "moving forward" as synonymous with progress, and assume that the speaker believes that any progress made during the 60s must be considered good, then the statement could potentially be interpreted as a circular argument (begging the question). however, without further context or clarification from the speaker, it is impossible to definitively classify this statement as a fallacy.

text: That is why I say that in this period of the sixties, America must move forward in every area.
actual_label:
answer: nothing (or possibly "begging the question", depending on how you interpret the statement)
explanation: while it may appear that the speaker is using a logical argument to justify their position, they are not actually providing any evidence or reasoning for why this period of the sixties requires america to move forward in every area. instead, they are simply stating their opinion without providing justification, and thus no fallacy is being committed. if, however, we interpret "moving forward" as synonymous with progress, and assume that the speaker believes that any progress made during the 60s must be considered good, then the statement could potentially be interpreted as a circular argument (begging the question). however, without further context or clarification from the speaker, it is impossible to definitively classify this statement as a fallacy.

text: Delores is a big supporter for equal pay for equal work. This is the same policy that all those extreme feminist groups support. Extremists like Delores should not be taken seriously -- at least politically.
actual_label: answer: guilt by association

text: "Four out of five dentists recommend Happy Glossy toothpaste. Therefore, it must be great."
actual_label:
'answer: appeal to false authority'
explanation: the argument relies on the assumption that four out of five dentists being in agreement is enough evidence to establish that happy glossy toothpaste is great. however, this does not account for potential conflicts of interest or other factors affecting the dentist's recommendation. moreover, it assumes that a majority opinion automatically equates to a reliable and accurate conclusion, which is not always the case.

text: Once they wear masks your anxiety will force you to demand the next step. biohazard suits? get real.
actual_label:
answer: fallacy of equivocation
explanation: the word "anxiety" can mean both a feeling of fear or apprehension and, in a medical context, a disease that affects the nervous system. here, the argument assumes that anxiety means the former, when in fact it's referring to the latter.

text: The last Democrat winner of the New Hampshire primary won the general election. This year, the winner of the New Hampshire primary will win the general election.
actual_label:
answer: fallacy of undistributed middle

explanation: the argument assumes that if a candidate wins the new hampshire primary in one election, they will necessarily win the general election in the same election. however, this does not take into account the possibility of other factors affecting the outcome of the general election (such as changes in public opinion or campaign strategies by other candidates). therefore, it is a fallacy where the middle term (the winning of the new hampshire primary) is not distributed to both extremes (winning and losing the general election), leaving an undistributed middle.

text: Men score better on math than women do. Jerry is a man. Therefore, Jerry is better at math than Sylvia, who is a woman.

text: Iran has moved forward with its nuclear weapons program. They're more dangerous today than they were four years ago. North Korea has moved forward with their nuclear weapons program, gone from one to two nuclear weapons to six to eight nuclear weapons. This vice president has been an advocate for over a decade for lifting sanctions against Iran, the largest state sponsor of terrorism on the planet. It's a mistake.

text: North Korea has moved forward with their nuclear weapons program, gone from one to two nuclear weapons to six to eight nuclear weapons. This vice president has been an advocate for over a decade for lifting sanctions against Iran, the largest state sponsor of terrorism on the planet. It's a mistake.
actual_label:
answer: hasty generalization

explanation: the reasoning here is based on a small number of cases (north korea going from one to six to eight nuclear weapons) and is being used to make a broad statement about the vice president's stance on lifting sanctions against iran. it's possible that the vice president has valid reasons for advocating for lifting sanctions, but the argument presented here does not provide enough evidence or information to support this conclusion. the argument jumps to a conclusion too quickly without considering other factors.

text: This vice president has been an advocate for over a decade for lifting sanctions against Iran, the largest state sponsor of terrorism on the planet. It's a mistake.
actual_label:
answer: appeal to authority (with a caveat)

explanation: the claim that iran is the "largest state sponsor of terrorism on the planet" is being presented as fact by an authority figure (the vice president). however, in this scenario, we are only shown one step of the thinking process. to accurately classify this statement as a fallacy, we would need to know if the vice president has provided any supporting evidence or reasoning for this claim beyond simply stating their opinion as fact. without additional context, it is possible that the vice president's authority on the matter is being used correctly to present a legitimate claim backed by evidence, making it incorrect to classify this statement as an appeal to authority in this instance.

text: You cant stop nature. Youre going to be infected if you havent already. We are always trying to fight nature. We just have to let it run its course.
actual_label:
answer: fallacy of false cause
explanation: the argument suggests that getting infected with something is a result of "fighting" nature, but there is no evidence provided that this is actually the case. the statement implies a causal relationship between the two concepts (fighting nature and getting infected) without any supporting evidence.

answer: nothing

text: My first day of basketball practice was easy, so it will always be easy.
actual_label:
answer: fallacy of false cause
explanation: the person is making a conclusion that something (basketball practice) will always be easy based on the fact that it was easy once. however, this does not necessarily mean that it will always be easy, as the difficulty level can change over time or due to various factors such as skill improvement, opposition, or fatigue.

answer: appeal to authority (specifically, appeal to unqualified experts)

text: efficient, effective, and highly-regarded. Their training program must be efficient, effective, and highly-regarded.

text: So now the far left is going to have to admit that there is a difference between the brains of men and women and their behavior isn't just a social construct that is created by what toys they are raised with? Looks like the exception is charging to the rescue of the norm. Plot twist!

answer: nothing (or possibly appeal to stereotype, if we interpret "the far left" as referring to a specific group with a stereotypical belief)
the statement does not present an argument and therefore it's not possible to classify it as a fallacy. it simply states an observation about a hypothetical situation without providing any premises or conclusions. if we interpret "the far left" as referring to a specific group, then the statement could potentially be considered an appeal to stereotype if the implication is that this group holds a certain belief. however, since the statement does not provide evidence or reasoning to support this claim, it is not possible to definitively classify it as a fallacy in this case.

text: What precisely makes these world leaders so convinced that climate change is a more urgent and massive threat than the incessant rampages of Islamist violence?

answer: question fallacy

explanation: the statement asks for an explanation as to why certain individuals are convinced about something (the urgency and magnitude of climate change), but does not provide any supporting evidence or reasoning for this belief itself. instead, it implies that the reader should already know the reasons for this belief. however, in a formal argument, one should always provide reasons and evidence for their beliefs, not simply ask others to guess them. by doing so, the statement commits the fallacy of asking a question rather than making a clear argument or claim with supporting reasoning.

text: There are 4.6 BILLION FUCKING YEARS of evolution on this planet across hundreds upon hundreds of millions of species and not a goddamned one of them, with the exception of you idiots, has any problem with killing for food. It's in the DNA of every single creature on this planet, and it's the SOLE FUCKING REASON that either of us exist. Killing for food is 100% acceptable and morally right, and the suffering of the animals involved is fucking irrelevant. Lions don't give a fuck about the screams of a wildebeest as they disembowel it for a dinner. There is nothing, save for your ego, that gives you a reason to act or feel any different.

answer: appeal to nature

text: It happened because I could work with people -- Republicans and Democrats. That's why we've had 24 retired generals and admirals, hundreds of business people, many of them Republican, support this campaign. You have to decide whether you want to change or not.

actual_label: answer: false dilemma. this statement presents a simplified choice between "getting better" and being unable to shoot down an aircraft, implying that there is no other option. however, there may be other possibilities such as not engaging with aircrafts or focusing on other aspects of skill improvement.

text: Social media is the worst. People don't realize how much of an effect it has on someone, especially his generation.
actual_label:
answer: circular reasoning

explanation: the argument relies on a premise that "people don't realize" about social media (that it negatively affects young people), but the conclusion is that social media is bad because it has a negative effect on young people. this creates a circle in reasoning, as the conclusion supports the premise and vice versa.

text: Anyone in the public eye who has any sort of mental health issue should rid themselves of their accounts if they possibly can.
actual_label:
the statement presents a type of argument known as an 'appeal to shame'. in this case, the argument is trying to make the claim that someone in the public eye with a mental health issue should hide or remove their accounts based on the notion that it is shameful to have a mental health issue and present oneself publicly. this is incorrect, as having a mental health issue is not shameful and should not be used as a reason to hide one's identity or presence online.

the reasoning behind this answer is that the argument relies on emotions (shame) to make its case, rather than providing evidence or facts to support the conclusion. the use of emotional manipulation in an argument can lead to flawed conclusions and unjustified actions, as seen in this example.

so, the answer would be 'answer: appeal to shame'.

text: China has people in internment camps and people in the middle east get stoned for not wearing head scarves, but it's social media that's the worst?
actual_label: answer: false equivalence

text: Mr. Gough supports the cell phone ban and he's an idiot, so we should let teachers keep their cell phones.
actual_label: answer: guilt by association

text: Bill, you drive a beat-up car from the 1980s. For this reason, we can never allow you to be a lifeguard at the community pool.
actual_label:
answer: false cause fallacy

explanation: the argument states that because someone drives an old car, they cannot be a lifeguard. however, there is no logical connection between the two facts. driving an old car does not inherently make someone unsuitable for the role of a lifeguard. therefore, it is a fallacy where cause and effect are incorrectly assumed.

text: The teenagers where rude and disrespectful therefore all teenagers are rude and disrespectful.

text: If you give the government *any* control over what is considered"hate speech", you are basically relinquishing your freedom of speech. It's a slippery slope. For example: saying"hateful" things about Islam becomes illegal. Let's say you criticise Sharia laws (laws based off of the rules set out in Islam for those who are unaware). Next thing you know, your own government has full power to censor this"hate", and you are persecuted simply for disagreeing with the laws of an ally nation. Governments have shown time and time again that they are more than happy to censor and abuse their peoples. Don't ever relinquish your freedoms willingly.
actual_label: answer: slippery slope fallacy

text: Governments have shown time and time again that they are more than happy to censor and abuse their peoples.
actual_label:
answer: argument from ignorance
explanation: the statement implies that since governments have shown a history of censorship and abuse, it is reasonable to assume that they will always do so in the future. however, this logic is based on the premise that if something has happened once or multiple times, it will necessarily happen again in the future without further evidence or reasoning. this fallacy is also known as "appeal to ignorance" because it assumes that a claim is true merely because it has not been proven false. in this case, the assumption that governments will always abuse their people is not supported by enough evidence to be certain.

text: That means it must be really good!
actual_label:
'answer: fallacy of circular reasoning'

explanation: the method described in the statement relies on a group of experts agreeing with each other, which is the conclusion of the argument. however, this agreement is used as a step to reach the final conclusion, creating a circle in reasoning where no useful information is being shared.

'answer: appeal to ignorance'

text: Animals aren't food for us. If you wouldn't eat a dog or cat, don't eat a cow or chicken. Even if you would eat a dog or cat, don't.

actual_label:
'answer: false cause'

explanation: the reasoning here is that because the dish is traditionally served in a certain way in its place of origin, it is justified to serve it in that manner elsewhere. however, this does not mean that there is a causal relationship between the dish's traditional serving and its justification for being served that way elsewhere. therefore, the argument is a fallacy of false cause (also known as post hoc ergo propter hoc), where it is assumed that because event b follows event a, event a caused event b.

text: all believe I would make a stronger commander in chief. And they believe it because they know I would not take my eye off of the goal: Osama bin Laden.
actual_label:
the given statement does not explicitly present a fallacy. however, it seems to suggest an argument from authority based on the experts' belief about the speaker's capability as a commander-in-chief, with the reasoning being their knowledge that the speaker would focus on finding osama bin laden. but without providing any evidence or context to confirm these experts' qualifications and relevance to this specific topic, it remains unclear whether they are actual authorities on this matter.

answer: answer: possible appeal to authority (insufficient information given)
